titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. VI. Rain, part of the Night and this morning, with frost, which crystalized the Streets so that I was constrained to omit my morning walk— My Catarrhal Cough continuing without remission— Mr Patterson and Mr Thomas of Baltimore paid me a morning visit— They are delegates from the Baltimore railroad company; and are here upon some application from them to Congress for assistance— They expressed themselves as they have repeatedly done before, for the aid which I gave them, in the services of several Engineers who were public Officers; and said they had now hopes of obtaining assistance; but complained of the hostility to them of C. F. Mercer— I walked round the Capitol Square, and upon my return was overtaken by Mr Silsbee. He spoke of the prospect of difficulty in agreeing upon a candidate for Governor in Massachusetts if Mr Lincoln should decline a
re-election— He said he understood Lincoln to have promised that he would not decline, if there should be a prospect of Otis’s being elected in his place. I had a harrassing day and evening; for having reached in my chapter upon the Russian and Turkish War the period of the commencement of hostilities in May 1828— I found myself almost entirely destitute of materials—having nothing but the English Annual Register of 1828 for the transactions of that campaign, and very much perplexed how to construct a narrative from that without making a servile copy of it— Baron Krudener had lent me a file of the French Journal of St Petersburg from April till September 1829. but it is quite incomplete and has not even a regular series of the bulletins of the Russian army: nor does it come down to the conclusion of the Treaty of Peace at Adrinople 14. September— The day and Evening were swallowed up in a hasty glance over the Russian bulletins and despatches and I was yet not able to make out a thread even for a summary of Events, nor could I write a line of my chapter— The day was gone too and I had not written a Letter— Read a few Letters in the second book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus; but my attention was so much distracted by my other enquiries that I more imperfectly understood these— Some of the Letters are written from Rome, Atticus being in Greece or Epirus—and some from Antium, Tres Tabernae and Formiae, where Cicero had a farm; Atticus being at Rome.— In one of the Letters from Formiae he humorously complains of being disturbed by a crowd of visitors—My house says he is a tavern bar-room, not a farm-house— Of the Formians in general I say nothing. They are not troublesome to me after ten in the morning. But here is my next neighbour Caius Arrius—he has almost become my bedfellow— He absolutely refuses to return to Rome, for the sake of philosophising with me every day, and all day long— Then on the other side there is that Sebosus, the intimate friend of Catulus— Where shall I take refuge? Faith I would forthwith start for Arpinum, if I had not reason to expect you here at Formiae, at least the day before the Nones of May— But only think to what men, my ears are doomed to listen. A man might make a cheap purchase, by an offer for my farm of Formiae, now while these men are with me— A fine time truly for “great undertaking, of deep meditation, and leisure.” And yet it shall be done—and with no sparing of labour.— This is his epistolary Style Painting—Characters—Satire—Sentiment—warm friendship—delicate compliment—ardent aspirations to great atchievement, inflexible resolution to accomplish it and persevering labour, all in the compass of six lines, expressed in the tone of familiar conversation and with perfect simplicity—
2. VI:45. Tuesday.— Daylight—

My Catarrhal Cough almost breaks me down. It was near Sun-rise when I rose— I lost my walk before breakfast; and my reading of the Epistles to Atticus— I am arrested in my narrative of the Russian and Turkish War; and found I had nothing but the English Annual Register of 1828 to make it up. The file of the French Journal of St. Petersburg sent me by Baron Krudener, is only of 1829 and very incomplete— I wrote to Mr Brent, of the Department of State, requesting the loan of their file for the last two years: and he sent it, but it was much more incomplete than that of the Baron— I sent to the Baron,
to enquire if he was at home, and to say that if he was I would call upon him. He immediately afterwards came to see me— I asked him if he had any narrative of the campaign of 1828 that he could lend me— He said he had a small French pamphlet of observations written he believed by General Jominy which he would send me. I asked also for the loan of a map which he promised. He said he had mentioned to his Government the substance of his preceding Conversations with me, and his wish to be furnished with documents relating to the Turkish War, to communicate to me; as I was engaged upon Memoirs relating to my own political career— I repeated my thanks for his kindness; and said that in frankness I ought to tell him I had another object in view, besides what personally concerned myself; in the enquiries I was making of him I could not now fully explain it to him; though I would hereafter— I trusted it was such as would not be disagreeable to his government, or to himself, which he said he did not doubt— I said I did not wish him to mention this to his Government, though I had thought proper to say so much to him to account for the trouble I had repeatedly given him in asking information of him— I spoke of the recent accounts from Europe— He had received nothing special, but said the Emperor had met with a very serious accident—having risen in the Night upon hearing one of his children cry in the chamber next to his—going from one chamber to the other he had fallen, and struck his head on the floor— He had been several days ill, and was entirely recovered— He spoke of the Affairs of Greece; said he thought it probable Russia had assented that Prince Leopold of Saxe-Coburg should be the Sovereign of Greece— That the consequence would be that Count Capo d’Istrias would retire; and that Prince Leopold within twelve or eighteen Months would find himself in a Hornet’s Nest in which he could not live— He said that this excessive anxiety of the British Government to keep Greece under their own controul arose from the fear of losing the Ionian Islands, where, as well as at Malta, they were much detested— Mr Krebs came after dinner, and told me he was a native of Philadelphia, but had resided some years at Frederictown Maryland— He said he proposed to return soon to Philadelphia, and that he came to see me, merely to gratify his curiosity— Met Mr Rush—walking.
3. IV.30. Wednesday.

Resumed the walk before Sun rise, which has been two days interrupted, and after my return read the remainder of the second Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus— They were written during the Consulate of Julius Caesar and of Bibulus; and are full of lamentations and of grievous anticipations of the future: he is indignant at the shameful triumvirate of Caesar, Pompey and Crassus. In the Letters towards the close of the book, he begins to be fearful of the manoeuvres practiced against him by Publius Clodius: who being of a Patrician family, became a Plebeian by adoption, in order that he might be enabled to stand as a Candidate for election as a Tribune of the People— And with the favour and assistance of Caesar he succeeded. Cicero sees the storm coming; with professed tranquility, but with real deep agitation— He hopes for support from Pompey; who fails him in his need— He declines offers from Caesar whose conduct as Consul he detested. He frequently throws out uneasiness at his situation; wishes that he had never meddled with public affairs, and frequently repeats the ardent desire of devoting himself entirely to literature and Study. At one time he proposes to undertake a great Geographical work; but soon after gives it up— The latest of the Letters vehemently urge
Atticus to come to his assistance at Rome— Baron Krudener sent me the French pamphlet on the Russian Campaign of 1828 against the Turks, which I read; but found it of little use for my purpose— Its object was to prove that it was not so disastrous to Russia, as was rumoured in France and England— He sent me also a copy of the Treaty of Akerman. Mr Potter was a visitor from Rhode Island who came alone— Lieut. Child and Mr Lee, young men who came together— Mr Pearce and Mr Whipple spent part of the Evening with me— Whipple is a Scholar, and talked much of the Orations of Demosthenes— I received and answered a Letter from Jos Blunt; but an examination of the newspaper accounts of the Campaign of 1828 harrassed my attention, and absorbed almost the whole day; without furnishing me with sufficient materials for the narrative—wrote very little— My wife and daughter were both very unwell.
4. IV:30. Thursday—

The flight of time, leaves me far in the rear of all my occupations Mr Wright was a member of several former Congresses from the State of Ohio; but is now here with the two friends whom he introduced to me, in attendance upon the Supreme Court of the United States. Mr Rush called and was conversing with me upon his late Mission to borrow money, for the three Cities of this District in Europe; in which he has been successful—but we were interrupted by Major Mercer’s coming in— Mr Rush succeeded by applying to the House of the Crommelin’s and against the opposition of the Barings in England, and of the Willink’s at Amsterdam— Major Mercer had heard, and much admired the recent Speech of Mr Webster, in defence of the Eastern Section of the Union— Fendall sent me General Dearborn’s book upon the Commerce of the Black-Sea, and brought a New-York newspaper for my Son John— Fendall is now the Editor of the National Journal and George Waterston the publisher— The property of the Paper has been purchased from Peter Force, who retires from the Establishment— My morning was almost wholly take up by visitors, and I wrote to Nathl. Curtis, and Mrs Boylston. Mrs Adams was confined to her bed, with an inflammatory sore throat Dr Huntt was here; and was followed by Mr Clarke with a number of leaches which my wife applied to her throat— I was several hours engaged in seeking accounts of the Campaign in Turkey of 1828. from the National Journal from July to December of that year— The scantiness of materials is vexatious, and the files both of the Department of State and of Baron, are provokingly deficient— I read this morning to the 20th. Letter of the third Book of the Epistles to Atticus—written while Cicero was in banishment, upon the negation obtained against him by Clodius. He was at Thessalonica, at the house of Cneius Plancius the Quaestor who received and harboured him. The Letters are written in great dejection of Spirit; and in a querulous tone not altogether Roman, nor philosophical. But his house at Rome and his two villas at Tusculum and Formiae had been destroyed. He was proscribed as a criminal and Clodius had introduced into his Law, provisions interdicting the People themselves from ever repealing it. And by a diabolical
refinement of malignity, the ground upon which his house stood had by a religious solemnity been consecrated to Liberty. In these Letters written during his exile there is no mixture of Greek.
5. V:30. Friday.

There was a small flight of Snow this morning which however did not supersede my walk. Mr Weaver and Mr Knight have been heretofore employed in the service of the United States in the construction of public roads, and are now engaged upon the Baltimore and Ohio Rail-road. Knight has been to inspect the Railroads in England— Mrs Adams continues very unwell with the sore throat; but somewhat relieved by the bleeding of the leaches— My own Catarrh continues but is this day less troublesome— I wrote to my Son Charles and to my nephew Lieutt. T. B. Adams— Received a Letter from my brother in which he mentions that the thermometer at Quincy last Sunday Morning was at 11. below 0. It was here at 11. above 0 the difference between the severity of the two climates. Dr Huntt, Mrs W. S. Smith and Mr Frye were here. I was gathering all the information that I could upon the Russian and Turkish War, and read an Article upon Moldovia and Wallachia in the North-American Review for October 1828— I read the Epistles to Atticus from the 20th. of the 3d. book, to the 3d. of the fourth— Those of the third book were all written while he was in banishment— The 23d. Letter contains his argument upon the nullity and absurdity of Laws pretending to be unrepealable— For in repealing the Law, says he, you repeal the very clause by which it is declared unrepealable— The Letters of the fourth book, were written in the four years immediately after his return to Rome— His exile continued about eighteen Months, but the last Letter of the third Book was written in January, and is utterly despairing. The first of the fourth book was dated in September, and gives an account of his return to Rome— The second mentions his Oration, to the Pontiffs for his House, and says that if he ever was any thing as an Orator, and even if he never was any thing before, yet this Oration was such as he could not deny to be eloquent— That it must be preserved as a model for young men, and promises to send him a copy— In this third he says distinctly that if Clodius and Milo should meet, he believes that Milo would kill Clodius— The description that he gives of the violence and corruption prevailing at Rome is almost incredible.
6. IV:30. Saturday.

I found the weather colder to my feelings this morning than it had been any other day this winter— Upon my return, after Sun rise upon suspending my thermometer in a Northern exposition it fell to 12 above 0. afterwards I suspended it at a Northern window: it rose afternoon to 20 and fell again in the Evening to 14. Mr Hadley came for a subscription to a Society for publishing Religious Tracts which I declined— Mr Frothingham paid a morning visit— Said he had a Letter from his wife; which mentioned that the prospects of Mrs Brooks’s health were very discouraging— Mr Johns, member of the House of Representatives from Delaware came and introduced Dr Naudain the newly elected Senator from that State. Coll. Chambers Senator from Maryland came with Mr John Sergeant of Philadelphia. Mr Chambers
told me that he proposed calling on me to-morrow, with an old acquaintance of mine by the name of Gilpin— All the members of Congress, are full of rumours respecting the volcanic state of the Administration— A busy-body Presbyterian Clergyman of Philadelphia named Ezra Styles Ely, is the principal mischief-maker in the affairs of Mr and Mrs Eaton. He has been called here for the third time to pacify internal commotions. He was here several days, but went away without accomplishing any thing— The President had determined to remove Branch, the Secretary of the Navy; but H. L. White the Senator from Tennessee, and it is said Edward Livingston went in deputation to the President and informed him that if Mr Branch should be dismissed, the Senators from North-Carolina would join the opposition, and all the dubious nominations now before the Senate would be rejected. H was also given to understand that Ingham the Secretary of the Treasury and Berrien, the Attorney General would resign— He concluded therefore to retain Mr Branch, and become a Mediator between him and Eaton to bring them to speaking terms together. Such is their present state—Ingham, Branch, Berrien, Towson have given large Evening parties to which Mrs Eaton is not invited— On the other hand the President makes her doubly conspicuous by an overdisplay of notice— At the last drawing room the Night before last she had a crowd gathered round her, and was made the public gaze— But Mrs Donelson, wife to the President’s private Secretary, and who lives at the President’s House, held no conversation with her. The Administration party is split up into a blue and a green faction, upon this point of morals; but the explosion has hitherto been deferred: Calhoun heads the Moral Party— Van Buren that of the frail sisterhood; and he is notoriously engaged in canvassing for the Presidency by paying his Court to Mrs Eaton— He uses personal influence with the wives of his partisans to prevail upon them to countenance this woman by visiting her— There is a story current here which whether true or false is significant of the general estimate of Van Buren’s character. It is that he asked for a private conversation with Mrs Donelson, and for three quarters of an hour urged her with pathetic eloquence to visit Mrs Eaton— That she defended as well as she could her own course; but being no match for him at sophisticating, she at last said—Mr Van Buren, I have always been taught that “Honesty is the best Policy”— Upon which he immediately started up; took his hat and departed— Mrs Eaton is as much a character as Van Buren— Dr. Sim and his wife are among her enemies— They live next door to her, and in a house leased by her husband. About a fortnight since Mrs Donelson was visiting Mrs Sim, and Mrs Eaton saw the carriage standing before the door— The next day Dr Sim received notice from Eaton, to quit forthwith the house, though his lease will not expire till next December— The story goes that a day or two afterwards, Mrs Eaton, telling her millaner; a Mrs Williams, of the notice given to Dr Sim to quit, said “if it had not been for that d——d old granny, nothing of all this would have happened”— Whether she spoke those or the like words on that occasion or not, is uncertain, but it is her Style of conversation—and there are many speeches of the same kind reported about the Country; as genuine examples of her ordinary discourse— John’s told me that when
she went to Philadelphia first, last Summer, she went to the same boarding house where he was lodging— That his landlady asked him if he was acquainted with Mrs Eaton, to which he answered that he was not, and did not wish to be— The second time she went to Philadelphia, though Mrs Barry the Postmaster General’s wife was with her, the same Landlady declined receiving her— I read this morning from the 4th. to the 16th Letter of the 4th. book of the Epistles to Atticus— They speak of the Dialogues de Oratore, and of those de Republica which were composed about that time— There is a curious passage about Britain in the sixteenth Letter—
7. V. Sunday. Fahrenheit 10. Snow.

When I rose this morning I found the thermometer outside of the Northern window at 12. On returning from my walk it had fallen to 10, about Sunrise. Heard Frothingham from Genesis 27.2. “I know not the day of my Death.” a very well written discourse upon Death— He spoke of the antient symbolical representations of death on monuments—A Genius with inverted and extinguished torch; and blamed the modern exchange of it for a Skeleton— He thought that our custom of holding out the idea of Death as hideous and horrible was ill-judge and expanded with much illustration the thought expressed by Lord Bacon, that there is in the human heart no passion so feeble, but it often overcomes the fear of death— The first part of the Sermon was discursive— Towards the close it marked the uncertainties of death as of three kinds— The time—the manner—and the consequences— The moral lesson from the uncertainty of the time, was the duty of being always prepared—from that of the manner, that it should not be caused or hastened by ourselves—from the consequences to others that we should leave consolations for those afflicted by our deaths in the memory of our Lives, and prepare the consequences to ourselves so that our departure from this life may be but entrance upon a better— In speaking upon Death, the chief difficulty of a preacher is to avoid common places too much beaten— Mr Frothingham had not much of them. He had taken something from Lessing as well as from Bacon; but there was no flagging of interest while he spoke. I called at Mrs Blake’s after the Service, and there saw Messrs Crowninshield and Whipple— J. Sergeant and E. F. Chambers, D. J. Pearce, and Gilpin afterwards came in; and Coll. Dwight as a visitor— Mr Gilpin remembered his having met me in London in the year 1796. which I recollected, but not his person, which in 34 years has undergone as great a change as mine— And mine is such that no one now knows me from the portrait painted of me by Copley that year, though it was then a very exact likeness— As I was returning from Church it began to Snow, and continued snowing till evening, but the thermometer rose only to 18. I kept house the remnant of the day. Read many pages in different chapters of that farrago of piety and of absurdity, sense and nonsense the Koran— Read Epistles to Atticus from 17th. of the 4th. to 11th. of the 5th. Book. The 18th. (last) of Book 4. tells the scandalous bargain of the Consuls and others upon which Montesquieu has commented— The 5th. Book consists of Letters written while Cicero was Proconsul in Cilicia; and upon his voyage and Journey thither— The first exhibits a picture of domestic discord, from the life between his brother Quintus and his wife Pomponia, Sister of Atticus— The most remarkable feature in those Letters is the constant and extreme anxiety with which he deprecates the continuance of his Proconsuler command beyond one year—and his passion for returning to that Scene of violence and corruption the City of Rome— He says there were those who did not believe him.
8. VI. Monday. Fahrenheit 12. Sun rose 7:00 6:50.

Finding the Thermometer this morning at 12 when I rose, and the Snow upon the ground so drifted as to make pacing troublesome, I postponed my walk till 3 in the afternoon, and wrote before breakfast upon my war chapter— I wrote a note to Mr Brent enquiring if he had not more numbers of the St. Petersburg Journal, and he sent me two with a note, to say that was all he had— I was ashore; and thought I should have no stores for my campaign, but the English Annual Register, when I received a Letter from Blunt; with the French Annuaire Historique Universel pour 1828. par C. L. Lesur—a work which it appears has been published yearly, commencing with 1818. It is in imitation of the plan of the English Annual Register; but with various modifications. I found upon a cursory glance at the Chapters upon Russian and Turkish Affairs, that it was more copious, more interesting and more impartial than the corresponding chapters in the English work. I gave to it the remainder of the day. I had read in the morning from the 12th. to the 20th. of the Epistles to Atticus— They turn upon many things which without a commentary I cannot understand— Upon his extreme anxiety to get rid of his proconsulship, after one year of service— The cause of which he explains in a few lines of the 15th. Letter—“The field is not large enough for that excursive Spirit, with which you are not unacquainted. It is incredibly tedious to me— There is no splendour of service for my industry. I forsooth am dispensing justice at Laodicea, and Aulus Plotius at Rome, and while our friend has but an army: I have the name of Commander of two scanty Legions? In short I do not want these things. I want light, the forum, the City, my home, you. I will bear this, as well as I can— But let it be only for a year.” The Picture that he draws of his own practice in the Government of the Province, contrasted with that of those who preceded him, gives but a gloomy idea of the Roman proconsular rule— The 20th. Letter gives the account of his taking Pindenissae on the day of the Saturnalia, and of his being saluted as Imperator— “My encampment says he, for a few days upon the Issus the same that was occupied against Darius, by Alexander, an Imperator, not a little better than either you or me”—
9. IV:30. Tuesday.— Fahrenheit 6—32—18

Finding my Thermometer this morning at 6. I was deterred from walking before breakfast; but observed the effect of holding a lanthern before the thermometer to mark the degree of Cold— It raised the mercury six degrees within the space of a minute— This was the severest morning there has been since the year 1822. Mr Hodgson called upon me, with a manuscript Arabic book of prayers, and an amulet three or four yards long; written upon parchment. These are of the manuscripts which he wishes the Government to purchase— I asked him many questions respecting the Government, and state of Science at Algiers and Constantinople; most of which he was not able to answer. He told me
Webster Daniel

that Mr M’Duffie, the Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means, of the House of Representatives had this morning informed him that the Committee had agreed to recommend an appropriation for an Office, connected with the Department of State, for the purpose of engaging his services; upon which I gave him my hearty congratulation— He said he should be indebted for it entirely to me— I sent him to Algiers in 1825 to learn as many of the oriental languages as he could; and he has learnt Arabic, Turkish, Persian, and the lingua franca— I walked between two and four— Met Mr Rush, who walk with me to the top of the avenue— We had company to dine, as per margin. Mr Webster upon enquiry being made when his last speech would be published said it was impossible to write down a speech made off hand. I asked Mr Frothingham if he had read Lessing’s dissertation upon the manner in which the Antients represented Death— He said he had, and that it was from that he had taken the Description of the Antient Monuments in his Sermon of last Sunday Morning— I read this morning only one Epistle to Atticus— The 21st. and last of the 5th. book—a great part of it was unintelligible to me: especially a story of a Cyprian named Marcus Scaptius, recommended to him by Brutus—of a debt due to Scaptius by the People of Salami; of his oppressive measures to obtain the payment; and of Cicero’s ineffectual interposition between the parties— He protected the Salaminians from the fraud and insolence of Scaptius, and is fearful of having thereby given offence to Brutus: but says he is sure of the approbation of his uncle
10. V:30. Wednesday.

Resumed again my morning walk, but the days have already so much lengthened that I cannot now go out at six and return before Sun rise— He was ten minutes risen on my return this morning— Mr Holmes, member of the Senate from Maine called and mentioned that he intended to speak again upon this Resolution of S. A. Foot’s upon the public Lands— Thomas H. Benton, a liar of magnitude beyond the reach of Firdinand Mendez Pinto, among his other proofs that Eastern men have always had a settled policy of hostility to the West, alledged in Senate, as he has been all last Summer publishing in the Missouri Newspapers, that I in this Spirit of hostility to the West had given up to Spain the boundary of the Rio del Norte, in the Florida Treaty— Holmes and S. Smith both in replying to Benton said that this Treaty was made by Mr Monroe, and his Cabinet, and that they knew I was the last person who had consented to take the boundary of the Sabine— Holmes said he proposed to speak again upon the subject, and wished to allude to this fact again— And to be sure of accuracy he had called to enquire, if I had a recollection of the facts in this case— I told him I had, and what they were; and I read to him the passages in my Diary during the month of February 1819 relating to that Negotiation— I told him that in all the Negotiations conducted by me while Secretary of State, whether with Spain, France or England, I insisted invariably upon all the claims of the United States to their utmost extent: and whenever any thing was conceded it was by direction of the President himself, and always after consultation in Cabinet Meetings and that it was especially so in the Negotiation of the Florida Treaty.
Mr John Pope, now Governor of the Territory of Arkansas called upon me. I sat with this person some years in the Senate of the United States— He afterwards married my wife’s Sister Eliza who died some years since. Mr Pope has been in Kentucky a rival and antagonist of Mr Clay, and at the late Presidential Election, was a partizan of General Jackson; who has rewarded him with the appointment of Governor of Arkansas— He thinks this not an equivalent for his merits, and has come to convince General Jackson of his fitness for a higher office— John Cranch came to request me to sit to him for my picture, which I promised to do. Mr Fendall brought some Newspapers. I spoke to him of the papers in the Boston Daily Advertiser, upon the Article in the January North-American Review upon Pitkin’s History of the United States; and recommended to him to notice them in the National Journal— He spoke of the Republication in the Telegraph at this time of the papers signed Massachusetts published in the National Intelligencer of January and February 1820 in answer to Otis’s One of the Convention— I lent him the Journal of the Hartford Convention— Mr T. B. Johnson dined and spent the Evening with us.
11. IV:30. Thursday.

In my walk this morning, I met Chief Justice Marshall near the head of the avenue, and he turned and walked down with me to its termination opposite the yard of the Treasury building. I asked him who, since the decease of the late Judge Washington, was the owner of President Washington’s papers. He said he did not know but that they were now in the possession of Mr Sparkes who was to publish his Letters, and some of the Letters to him— I asked the judge if there ever had been an adjudication in England, of the property of Epistolary Correspondence— He knew of none. I mentioned the opinion or statement in a late number of the North American Review, that the property is in the writer of the Letter, to whom or to whose Representatives it ought to be returned after the decease of the receiver— He said he had formed no deliberate opinion upon the question, but that his first crude impression was that the property was in the receiver, a property qualified by the confidence of the writer— I mentioned to him the extraordinary character of the recent publication of Mr Jefferson’s papers; which have given rise to a scene as extraordinary in the Senate of the United States— Jefferson makes a minute 13 February 1801. that Edward Livingston told him, Bayard had offered Sam. Smith the Office of Secretary of War, if he would vote for Burr which W. C. Nicholas had confirmed. Mr Jefferson’s Executor now publishes this minute— Hayne last week to gratify the malignity of his nature, reads from a volume of Jefferson’s works, his tale of my having told him that certain federalists in New-England, during the War plotted a dismemberment of the Union during the late War— No answer was made to this: but Clayton a Senator from Delaware, read this minute about Bayard; and called upon Sam Smith and Edward Livingston to say whether it was true. Smith declared in the most explicit manner that neither Bayard nor any other man ever made any such proposal to him. Edward Livingston said he had tasked his memory to the utmost, and had been unable to recollect anything about it— Benton bristled up, and blustered about attempts to impeach the veracity of Mr Jefferson— Clayton answered that his object was not to impeach
the veracity of Mr Jefferson, but to vindicate the character of Mr Bayard, and that he had attained his object— That Mr Benton had chosen to fall into a furious passion about it, which to him Clayton was a matter of great Indifference— I said the most extraordinary part of this minute of Jefferson’s was that it was the direct reverse of the real fact: as Mr Bayard had told me what passed at that interview between him and Smith— The Judge said he had also told it to him. He added that he himself had been here, a witness of that Scene—altogether indifferent upon which of the two men the choice of the house would fall, and that by comparing what he then saw, with what afterwards came to pass, there were certain conclusions which it was very difficult to resist—but he did not say what they were. I suppose he meant that Livingston, who was there making his own bargain for his vote; told Jefferson this tale of Bayard’s offers to Smith, to make Jefferson out-bid Burr for Livingston’s own vote— Livingston was accordingly appointed District Attorney at New-York; and in due time went off with a hundred thousand dollars of the public money, to Louisiana: the judgment for which has never been paid till within the last six Months— I passed this day at home without interruption; and read yesterday and this day the 6th Book of the Epistles to Atticus. Still from his Cilician Government. Read loud this Evening to Mrs Adams an Article, in the Westminster Review of April 1829. upon the Court and family of Napoleon
12. V. Friday.

My performance of my daily task depends upon my rising at least as early as five O’Clock, and upon my returning from my daily walk of four Miles before breakfast— This was my wife’s birth-day and she enters upon her fifty sixth year— My Sons wife passed the day with Mrs Frye, who is confined, by illness to her chamber. I returned Mr Pope’s visit at Gadsby’s Hotel; but he was not within and I left a Card— About two O’Clock this afternoon, there was a fire, and two small brick houses in the Pennsylvania Avenue were burnt, one inhabited by a hair-dresser named Shepherd—the other by the Presbyterian Minister Dr Laurie— I had visits this Evening from Mr Southard, and from Mr John Taliaferro, a member of the House of Representatives from Virginia. Mr Southard is here upon business before the Supreme Court— He forgot to bring with him the paper that I had lent him at Philadelphia— He comes to sustain a cause in which the States of New-Jersey and New-York are at issue. I read three Letters of the 7th. Book of the Epistles to Atticus— In the preceding book there are three of four Letters of apology concerning a pecuniary interest of Brutus in no wise creditable to him. Bonds had been taken from the inhabitants of Salamis to one Scaptius—for a large sum of money. Scaptius with a Troop of Horse furnished him by Appius another Proconsul, had summoned the Senate of Salamis; and surrounding with his horsemen the place of their meeting to compel them to pay the money; held them in duress till five of the Senators perished with Hunger— Cicero upon his arrival hearing of this, not only took away the horsemen from Scaptius, but even sent them out of the Island— But he sent for the Salaminian Senators and obtained a promise from them to pay the money within the terms allowed by Law; terms which Scaptius rejected, insisting upon usurious interest. It appears that Brutus took much offence at Cicero’s humane interference, and finally made known that the debt was really due to him, and that the name of Scaptius was merely a cover to the transaction— Cicero complains that all the Letters of Brutus to him are haughty and overbearing— The Letters of the seventh Book were written precisely when the civil war between Caesar and Pompey was kindling. Cicero saw distinctly what a fearful thing it was, and to what fatal consequences it must lead. His Letters are full of the embarrassments of his own situation— He saw that the cause of Pompey was the cause of his Country; but that Caesar in all probability would prevail; and
even if Pompey should be victorious there would still be an end of public liberty. In the third Letter he answers a question which Atticus had just put to him in one of his: what he would say—when the question should be asked of him in Senate “What say you, Marcus Tullius?[”] I will answer says he “I concur with Cneius Pompeius—but I will privately advise Pompey to an accommodation— For this is my Sentiment—the danger is extreme, you who are at Rome know best—but this I see that we have to do with a man desperately audacious, and prepared for every thing—that every convict, every man of ruined reputation, every man who deserves conviction or infamy, goes for him; almost all the young men, all that worthless rabble of the City, the popular tribunes, with Caius Cassius, and the whole tribe of insolvent debtors—far more numerous I learn, that I had expected— That Cause wants nothing but a Cause— In every thing else it abounds.”— This picture was as true as it was gloomy.
13. VI:30— Saturday.

I rose so much later than usual that I could not go out till after Sun rise and my occupations for the day accordingly suffered. Mr Frothingham called, and mentioned, that he proposed to leave the City; on Monday morning, to return to Boston. I invited him to dine with us to-morrow; which he promised. There was an auction of Books this Evening, which my Son John attended— I wrote to Charles and continued writing upon the chapter of the Russian and Turkish War— I read from the 3d. to the 13th. Epistle of the 7th. Book to Atticus— In all these Letters he shews the most earnest desire to avoid the civil War; and time after time repeats that he thinks it would be much better to yield to Caesar every thing that he required, than to set him at defiance by War. In the 6th. after expressing the same opinion, he adds you will enquire “what think you? Not what I shall say— I think every thing is to be done, to avoid the resort to arms: I shall say the same as Pompey: nor am I ashamed so to do— This is another sore evil in the Commonwealth: and for particular reasons it would not be right for me to differ from Pompey in affairs of so much importance.” In the 7th. after repeating his opinion that for the sake of Peace, Caesar’s demands should be complied with, he adds “you say, make battle, sooner than submit. but how—if vanquished to be proscribed? if victorious, still to be enslaved? What then you ask, will you do?— Like the herd—when turned out they follow the flock of their own kind— As the bullock in the herd, so I will follow, the good men, or those who are called good; though they rush to ruin.” In the 8th. he tells of a conversation he had had with Pompey, who did not appear to him even to desire Peace— He had a vehement contempt for Caesar, in the Event of War; and entire confidence in his own force and in that of the Republic. In the 10th. he tells Atticus, of the sudden stop he had taken to leave the City, before day, and says He knows not what Pompey will do—“But unless I am insane, every thing yet done has been foolish and heedless”— In the 11th. there are excellent moral reflections upon the madness and wretchedness of Caesar’s conduct; and upon the humiliating abandonment of the City by Pompey. In the 12th. he mentions a conference he had held with the Consul Lentulus at Formiae— All he says was full of fear and of error— In all these Letters he asks advice from Atticus what he shall do, and how he shall dispose of his wife, daughter, and Son, as well as of himself. In the 13th he notices the proposals of Lucius Caesar.
14. IV:45— Sunday— Fahrenheit 20.

Heard Mr Frothingham from Romans 6.1 [“]What shall we say then? shall we continue in sin, that grace may abound? 2. God forbid.” This Sermon was quite equal to those I had heard the two preceding Sunday— It was upon the abuse of the goodness of God 1. By ingratitude 2. by transgression 3. By impenitence— The introduction, explained the occasion upon which this sentiment was expressed by the Apostle— As the conclusion of an Argument from the abounding mercies of God, surpassing even the sins of his creatures— This occasion he said had passed away— It was applicable to the converts to Christianity of that age, and could have no reference to the circumstances of our own times. But there was a slight modification of it quite applicable at this day, and to multitudes of our fellow Christians of whom if we could not say shall we continue in sin, in order that grace may abound; it might with great propriety be asked, shall we continue in Sin, because Grace abounds? This was but too common— And he illustrated each of the points in which he had specified the abuses of the divine goodness, with great force—enlarging especially in beautiful language, and by no common place thoughts upon the vice of intemperence. The composition of Mr Frothingham’s Sermons, is remarkable among other merits by the method of his divisions: resembling those of the French preachers; particularly Massillon. After the morning Service I called to see Mr Rush; but he was not at home— Then at Baron Krudener’s, where I found young Fulton, who introduced himself to me. The Baron told me that two Naval Officers, Captain Avinoff, and Mr Amossoff, with whom he sent me Cards a few days since, were at his house. He said he was about purchasing a Corvette of 30 Guns which had been built at Philadelphia, for the Mexican Government, but which had remained here because it had not been paid for. He said that these Officers had been sent here to visit and examine our naval Establishments— That Captain Hull had been very obliging in shewing them the Navy-Yard here; and that the President had spoken to him in liberal terms, upon the subject of their inquiries. But he thought they had met with some obstacles, which would not have occurred under the preceding Administration; particularly in regard to the construction of the powder magazines, in our ships of War— I had a long conversation with the Baron upon the present state of the Affairs of Greece, which I told him I thought it would yet take a long time to settle— He said he was going in a few days to Philadelphia; to stay there perhaps a fortnight, and then return here. As I was coming home I met at my door, Mr White the Delegate from Florida, who was calling to pay me a visit— He has obtained the withdrawal of nomination of two of the persons temporarily appointed to Office in Florida, during the Summer, and hopes to obtain the rejection by the Senate of two nominations actually made— Messrs. Sergeant, Everett and Frothingham dined with us— I intended to have gone with Mr Frothingham to the evening Service; but he went off and left me with our other Companions—and I found it too late when they were gone. Mrs Adams dined with us—
15. IV:45. Monday.

Mr Bell, the Senator from New-Hampshire called on me with a subscription paper for a new Edition of Belknap’s History with Notes, by Mr Farmer, of Concord; to which I readily put down my name— Mr Bell spoke of the nominations to Offices now before the Senate, and said that in the whole forty years since the Government of the United States has existed it would be impossible to collect a number of infamous and degraded characters
in the list of Officers of the United States, equal to that in the list of Nominations now before the Senate. He had hoped that the whole tribe of Editors of Newspapers would be rejected; for he thought it the most dangerous precedent that could be established; and if now sanctioned by the Senate, he despaired of its ever being controuled hereafter— Possibly Isaac Hill might be rejected; he feared no other of the Printers would be. Henry Lee he believed would be rejected. The evidence of his infamy, in transactions of private Life was accessible, and would if necessary be produced. But I very strongly doubt whether any one of the nominations will be rejected. He said that with regard to the arbitrary removals from Office; there was not an entire agreement between the opponents of the present Administration themselves as to the Constitutional principle— He inclined to the opinion that the concurrence of the Senate to the removal may be inferred as necessary, because it is necessary for an appointment— But some were of opinion that the president had only the power of suspending an Officer, and if the person whom he nominated as Successor should be rejected by the Senate, then the previous incumbent still continued in Office— I said that the Discretionary power of the President to remove was settled by Law, and by the uniform practice of forty years, I thought it correctly settled; but if the discretion was palpably abused, I thought it impeachable misdemeanor— In questioning however this abuse of power, I thought it would be unsafe and certainly unsuccessful to advance any new principle. He said there would be a call this day, for the detected correspondence between Timberlake and Eaton, as bearing upon the nomination of Amos Kendall. I told him I thought it doubtful whether the really significant Letters would be sent if called for. Mr Bell told me that he was almost discouraged as to the permanency of our Institutions; witnessing as he does the profligacy with which the Government is administered; and the tendency of all corruption, from bad to worse— My own hopes are better— I have seen this Country once go through a political convulsion, nearly as profligate as the present, and recover from it to pure and quiet elections— I hope that it may do so again. Every present symptom indeed is gloomy and discouraging—every thing looks to decay and not to improvement. Every thing has an aspect of pulling down, and not of building up— Major Lomax and Edward Tayloe called here together— And Mr Whittlesey in the Evening with a Mr Wilson, and Mr Tichenor who was for some time a purser in the Navy.
16. IV:45. Tuesday.

No interruption, and after the morning walk, I had a continual pressure of occupation; writing little but reading almost the whole day— I finished the Book of Ecclesiasticus; or Wisdom of the Son of Sirach; which I have often read before; and always with much satisfaction— It was written during the time of the Ptolemies, and after the age of Plato. It is in imitation of the Proverbs of Solomon; but like most of the other Aprocryphal books with the continuity of thought usual in Greek compositions— It is remarkable that in the Scriptures, excepting one or two allusions in Paul’s Epistles, there is no reference to the Grecian Literature. They appear to have had no acquaintance with it— Nor had any of the Grecian writers any acquaintance with the Literature of the Hebrews— Juvenal and Tacitus had heard something of the Hebrew Books, but certainly did not understand them— Longinus quotes the first chapter of Genesis, for an example of sublimity; but when Longinus lived Christianity was soon to become the Religion of the Roman Empire
The Grecian principles of composition would have been improved by a critical analysis of the Hebrew Books— Sententious sayings in Greece preceded the continuous Style— The figurative language of Pythagoras, was more obscure than the Proverbs of Solomon— The Sayings of the Wise men of Greece were much of the same character— The Son of Sirach is more diffusive and more didactic— It resembles an Edition of the Proverbs of Solomon with a Commentary— The morals inculcated in the book are righteousness, Piety to God, Reverence to Parents and to old age— Severe discipline to children, prudence, temperance, Justice, and Fortitude— There is great change in passing from these to the Epistles of Cicero— I have read within the last three days from the 14th to the 26th. and last Letter of the 7th. Book, and twelve of the eighth Book. In this last there are two Letters from Pompey to Cicero, requesting him to come to him at Brundisium; with Cicero’s Answers, declining to go— There is also a Letter from Pompey to the Consuls Caius Marcellus, and Lucius Lentulus; and three Letters from Pompey to Lucius Domitius. The Letters of Pompey are all well written— Throughout these Books, Cicero continues to shew extreme solicitude and anxiety what he shall do— His friendship for Pompey constrains him to follow his fortunes, while his opinion is that Caesar will prevail, and he has evidently a much higher opinion of Caesar’s abilities than of Pompey’s— The characters of the two men are well exhibited in Lucan’s Pharsalia— I have also looked into the first Book of Caesar’s Commentaries on the Civil War, to mark how he tells his own Story. He does not make it much better— It is a piteous tale to read— My chapter on the Turkish and Russian War harrasses me— I am drawing towards a close of the campaign of 1828—and was hunting up the Journal of St. Petersburg for accounts of that of 1829. which I must collect from the Russian Bulletins— It will be a long and very tedious compilation.
17. VI:30— Wednesday.

Rose two hours later than my usual time, and was proportionably belated in my walk: and abridged in the occupations of the day. Had a morning visit from General Harrison late Minister Plenipotentiary to the Republic of Columbia; recalled to make way for Tom P. Moore, a man generally despised, but who has ingratiated himself with Bolivar as he did with General Jackson by sycophancy— Harrison was but a short time there; but long enough to get involved in some of their party divisions— It was perhaps impossible to avoid it— Harrison says that Bolivar’s friends openly avow their purpose to make Bolivar king or Emperor and say that General Jackson intends to do the same in this Country. He says also that he did not while he was Minister, take any part in the internal dissensions of that People, but that after he had been succeeded by Mr Moore, he had written a Letter to General Bolivar, to dissuade him from the establishment of a Monarchy— Which Letter he said he intended to publish. I asked him if it was true that Venezuela had determined to separate from the Republic of Colombia— He thought it would, if Bolivar should assume the Crown— This however he believed he would not do. He would content himself with the title of President for Life— He said that Bolivar had applied to the British Government, for support to his project of establishing a Monarchy and the answer was that Great Britain took a deep interest in the welfare of the people of Colombia, but would not interfere with their interior Government. If they should however call a European Prince to the throne, no English Prince could accept it, and there would be great inconvenience should the choice fall upon any other than a Prince of Spain. The conduct of Bolivar, has for many years been equivocal— As a Military Leader, his course has been despotic and sanguinary— His principles of Government have been
always monarchical, but for himself he has repeatedly played off the farce of renouncing his power and going into retirement— He still holds out this pretence, while at the same time he cannot disguise his hankering after a crown— Mr Johnson dined and spent the Evening with us— I read from the 13th. to the 16th. and last of the eighth Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus, and two of the ninth Book— They are full of censure upon Pompey whose cause he follows, and of admiration from Caesar whom he detests— In the 13th. he says—Do you not see upon what a man the Republic has fallen? how keen—how watchful—how ready— Faith if he should commit no murder or robbery, they who have most dreaded him will come most to love him— In the 15th. he encloses copy of a Letter from Balbus to him, earnestly entreating him to use his influence to reconcile Caesar and Pompey together; and protesting that Caesar will do any thing that he Cicero should advise, and that he has a most earnest desire to be reconciled with Pompey. Cicero complains that this is treating him with derision.
18. V. Thursday.

Young Dawes came to solicit a loan of 600 dollars, for which he is under so severe a pressure that if he cannot obtain it by Saturday he fears his Notes will be protested, and his credit will then be lost. His brother who is his partner with a license as Auctioneers is gone to Boston, to endeavour to raise money upon certain real Estate—but he wants the money in the mean time— I was unable to give the assistance which they need— Lieutt. Armistead is of the Marine Corps, and has returned lately from the Mediterranean. Commodore Crane was here also having lately returned in the Delaware Ship of the Line— I had not much opportunity of conversing with him, Mr Pope having come in while he was here— An invitation had been sent to Mr Pope to dine with us on Saturday: he came to say that he expected to go to Leesburg to-morrow not to return this week; and if not that he was engaged for Saturday— Mrs Smith was here, and in the Evening Mr Bailey with Mr Larned. Bailey told me that the nomination of Lemuel Williams as Collector of the Port of New-Bedford, in the place of Russell Freeman removed, was yesterday rejected by the Senate 34 to 11. but that this day it was agreed that the vote should be reconsidered. I received a Letter from Mr Curtis and Mrs Boylston, with an enclosure from Mr Lowell. I was buckled to my labour upon the Turkish War, till I was compelled to drop my pen, propter lippitudinem— I read from the second to the tenth Epistle of the Ninth Book to Atticus, written at the time when Pompey had abandoned Rome and fled to Brundisium: pursued and besieged by Caesar— Cicero was all this time at Formiae; undetermined whether to follow Pompey, to go to Rome, or to remain where he was— Caesar neither proscribed portions nor plundered private property. Pompey threatened both, and many of his partizans, did so more than himself. Cicero was constantly reproaching himself for not following Pompey, and constantly censuring Pompey’s conduct— The 4th. Letter in this book, is more than half in Greek—a Series of questions which he says he is discussing with himself, as to the duties of a Citizen, in various cases, when his Country is oppressed by a tyrant— There is a Letter from Caesar to Cicero, requesting him to meet him at Rome; and assist him with his Counsels; his dignity, and his reputation.— A Similar Letter from Balbus and Oppius to Cicero, and one from Balbus alone. Caesar felt the want of the countenance of so distinguished a Man. The tenth Letter is a long review of all the Letters recently received by him from Atticus. In speaking of Pompey; he says that at the bottom of his Soul, he Sullaturises and proscripturises. Meaning to say that he intends to follow the example of Sylla’s proscriptions.
19. IV:15. Friday— Sun rose 6:36.

The days are rapidly lengthening, and I have now to go out before half past five to return from my walk before Sun rise. I saw its first beam this morning from the Eastern Window. Mr Foot and Mr Clayton, Senators from Connecticut and Delaware paid me a morning visit followed by Mr White Delegate from Florida, and the newly appointed Marshal of that Territory— The debate in the Senate upon Foot’s Resolution concerning the Public Lands, continues, and has elicited a number of able and animated Speeches— Benton and Hayne, by a joint and concerted attack upon the Eastern portion of the Union, proposed to break down the Union of the Eastern and Western Sections, and of restoring the old joint operation of the West and the South against New-England— Benton’s object is personal advancement, and plunder— Hayne’s personal advancement by the triumph of South-Carolina over the Tariff and Internal Improvement, and Calhoun’s succession to the Presidency— The assault was so vehement and rancorous, and desperate, that it roused the Spirit of the East, and Webster, and Sprague have made eloquent Speeches in its defense— Holmes finished a powerful Speech this day. Barton has replied to the personalities of Benton, by personalities, cutting because founded in truth— There is an other question now in sharp discussion upon the nominations before the Senate in the place of persons removed.— Mr Clayton asked my opinion upon the construction of the words in the Constitution authorizing the President to fill vacancies happening during the recess of the Senate— I gave him my opinion, and also mentioned my experience of the practice under the Government, almost coeval with its existence. Mr Clayton seemed to think that the President could not remove an Officer without the concurrence of the Senate— We were interrupted in this conversation by the visit of Mr White and the Marshal of Florida— I dined at Mr Rush’s with Messrs. Coxe, Dangerfield, J. D. Dickinson, H. W. Dwight, E. Everett, Chevalier Finoli, J. S. Johnston, R. M’Call. C. F. Mercer, R. Peters, Prince, Rousseau Swann. B. O. Tayloe, Webster, and Wirt. The Chevalier Finoli was a fellow passenger with Mr Rush, in his voyage from England; an Italian Agent for Mexican Mining Companies in England— Mr Mercer after dinner spoke with great severity and indignation of Mr Jefferson and of the recent publication of his works. He said he had no opinion of Mr Jefferson’s principles since he saw a copy of the Correspondence between him and Coll. Walker, certified as authentic by Chief Justice Marshall, and another person— I asked him if Jefferson Randolph had published that Correspondence, as part of his Grandfather’s works— He laughed and said no.
20. V. Saturday.

Mr Cox and General Davis came as a Committee from the Subscribers to a Ball on the 22d. instt. Washington’s Birth day; to invite my attendance which I declined; as I go to no public places. This is to be an uncommonly splendid celebration—at the Theatre— We were invited also to another party called the Citizens Birth-Night Ball, to be given at the Masonic Hall, and said to be of the Masonic Society: why they had a different celebration from the others I am not informed. Coll Worth and Coll. Morgan also paid me a morning visit— They are here upon a Court-Martial, to try the Adjutant General Coll. Jones, arrested upon Charges presented by Major-General Macomb— I asked what those charges were— Coll. Worth said they
related to some arrangements in the publication of the Army Register. Each of those Officers is over-sensitive to his own official privileges and prerogatives, a disposition common to almost all the Officers of the Army, and the source of those dissensions and collusions which make it I believe the most quarrelsome body in the world— But while General Macomb is attempting to Cashier the Adjutant General, Congress are thinking of pulling down the Major General himself; a bill being already reported by the Military Committee for abolishing that Office— Mr M’Call, the Navy Agent at Gibraltar, now home upon a visit, also called— Yesterday and this day I have read from the 11th. to the 19th Letter of the ninth, and ten Letters of the tenth Book of Cicero’s Epistles to Atticus. There are enclosures of Letters from Caesar, from Oppius and Balbus, and Coelius and Mark Antony to Cicero—and one Admirable Letter from Cicero to Caesar— The 18th. Letter of the ninth Book gives the account of the meeting and conference between them— Caesar urged Cicero to go to Rome, and attend the Meetings of the Senate convened by him there— Cicero asked him if he should go, whether he should be at liberty, freely to express his opinions. Should I dictate to you? said Caesar. Well said Cicero— I shall say, that the Senate should not allow you to go to Spain, or to send your army into Greece; and I should lament much that you have done against Pompey— But said Caesar, I will not have those things said— So I thought said Cicero—but I will not be there; where I must either speak thus, and say many other things about which it would be impossible for me to be there—or else not to go— Caesar finally asked him to think further of it; which Cicero promised—and they parted— From that Time Cicero waited only for an opportunity to cross over into Macedonia to join Pompey— Caesar and Coelius and Antony afterwards wrote him Letters urging him not to go out of Italy; but he determined to go— I finished reading also the Article in the Edinburgh Review upon Captain Hall’s Travels and Cooper’s Notions of a batchelor— There is a feeling of Chagrin and irritation in every thing that the English Travellers and Reviewers write or say about America; but they say nothing worse, perhaps nothing half so bad of us, as we say or think of one another. It is somewhat singular, though perhaps not an unnatural inconsistency, that while we have so much self complacency in our national Variety, we have so much mutual hatred and contempt for one another
21. V. Sunday.

My labour grows upon my hands, and it is within a week of the time when I should have accomplished the task I had undertaken— It is not yet half finished— This morning after returning from my walk I took it up, instead of Cicero, and wrote till breakfast time— I went to the Unitarian Church but found there was no preaching there— I returned through a sprinkling of Rain— Met Count Menou, who insisted on turning and walking with me, to give me the benefit of his Umbrella. I went to Mr Campbell’s Church, and heard him from John 3.16. [“]For God so loved the World, that he gave his only begotten Son, that whosoever believeth in him should not perish but have everlasting life.” Mr B. O. Tayloe was in the pew. Mr Campbell gave notice that if the weather should permit there would be an Evening service, but the Evening like the day was foul, and I did not go out again— Mr Fendall paid me a morning visit. I wrote
two pages of the Russian and Turkish War, and read from the 11th. to the 18th. Epistle of the Tenth book; with this close the Letters written before Cicero left Italy to follow the fortunes of Pompey— From the seventh to the tenth Book, are all the letters, written from the time when Caesar crossed the Rubicon, until Pompey took refuge in Greece—one of the most important periods in human history— The breaking down of the Roman Republic— There is an appearance of irresolution and indecision in the Character of Cicero at this time; but his situation was such as human nature could scarcely sustain— He resisted all the fascinations of Caesar, and the threats of his Subalterns Antony and Coelius— I read likewise to Mrs Adams in the Evening the first Article in the English Quarterly Review of last January upon Russia— The works reviewed are the Travels of a Dr. Granville Coll de Lacy Evans’s pamphlet on the Designs of Russia, and an answer to it— The Reviewer ridicules unnecessarily Dr Granville—proves very decisively the utter absurdity of Coll. Evans’s apprehensions—especially that the Russians should march from Constantinople to overthrow the British Empire in India; but the Reviewer betrays a rancour against Russia, more than any I had ever witnessed before— I left a Letter to my Son Charles partly unfinished—
22. IV:30. Monday.

I read and wrote this morning, before going out till 6 O’Clock. Met Chief Justice Marshall, who turned and walked with me to the end of the avenue. He thinks there has been within his memory a manifest mitigation of the Winter climate in this Country— Less Snow—less cold in degree— Shorter Winters— My own observation agrees with this opinion. Mr Norton who called upon me with S. Clark is a member of the house of Representatives from the district formerly represented by Albert H. Tracy, who married his daughter. Tracy is now a member of the Senate of New-York; and Clark said would be the Candidate of the Anti-Masons at the next Election for Governor— I asked them how the anti-masonic fever came on in the State of New-York— Norton said in substance that it was going on conquering and to conquer— That it had elected, and his Son in Law Tracy to the Senate of New-York. That he believed it would carry the next election for Governor of New-York; and they expected would next year command Majorities in Massachusetts and Pennsylvania— He said he had a Letter from Mr Tracy, advising them here to take no part in favour of either of the old hack candidates for the next Presidency; meaning Van Buren; Calhoun and Clay—for that the Antimasons might very probably be able hereafter to start and carry a Candidate of their own; or at all Events decide the contest by throwing their weight into the Scale of the one whom they should prefer. I asked Clark if he was not himself a Mason— He said he had been—but that he had renounced the craft before this question about Morgan had arisen— Clark enquired of me, if I had not told Mr Storrs, that I knew Mr Platt whom I had caused to be appointed Postmaster at Utica, to be a Jackson man— I said I had some recollection of having told Mr Storrs, that I had heard so— Clark said he himself had been a candidate for the Office, and had been well satisfied with the appointment of Mr Platt— That Platt had now been removed, and a third person had been appointed in his place— That they were all three Jackson men, and he wanted to get Mr Platt restored— I told him that
if I had known Platt to be a Jackson Man, that had been no recommendation of him to me— That I should have preferred the appointment of a friend of my own, but I directed the appointment of Platt, because he was best qualified for the place and was most desired by the Inhabitants of the Place— I had been exceedingly censured by my friends for appointing Jackson men at all, and I had certainly not appointed them in preference to my own friends with pleasure— I had neither appointed Mr Platt nor him because they were Jackson men— He said that he, had been for Jackson, because he was against any person’s being President more than one term— But there was a more conclusive impulse with him than that— He saw it was likely to be the strongest side— The person who came with General Harrison and Coll Torrens, was an agent for the Colombian loan-contractors in England— He has been residing some years at Bogota, and was now ordered out of the Country— Judge Thruston and his Son passed an hour with me this Evening— The judge is exceedingly indignant at Mr Van Buren, for dismissing his Son, from Office as Clerk in the Department of State; and says that he pronounced the word “Scoundrel,” very energetically to the face of Mr Van Buren, and in the hearing of a dozen persons at Marshal Ringgold’s, at the wedding party upon Dr Huntt’s Marriage with Ringgold’s daughter— Mr Noble of Indiana it seems has this day been making a speech in no wise to the honour of Mr Van Buren.
23. V:15 Tuesday.— Shrove Tuesday.

There was frost again last Night and this morning; but the river is open, and the winter is essentially broken up— I had no morning visitors, but in the Evening Miss James and Miss Danforth came to solicit a contribution for the infant School; and brought me a Letter of Solicitation from the Revd. Joshua N. Danforth— They said they had collected nearly contributions enough for the erection of their buildings, and when that should be completed they hoped they should not need to beg any longer— A man by the name of Stewart brought me a Razor Strop superior as he said to all others, which he left with me to try— My reading and writing tries me by peine forte et dure.— In the Bible I am upon the prophet Isaiah— Sublime beyond all written composition, in some particular passages—obscure, unintelligible almost throughout— A collection of rhapsodies, without apparent connection with one another—wild and wonderful—and of which it seems to me the more I read, the less I understand— The National Intelligencer had this day half a recent speech of Mr Webster, which has been much celebrated in reply to a violent invective against him of A. Y. Hayne— It fills almost two sides of the paper, and the other half is to come on Thursday. It is defensive of himself, and of New-England, but carries the war effectively into the enemy’s Territory— It is a remarkable instance of readiness in debate—a reply of at least four hours to a Speech, of equal length— It demolishes the whole fabrick of Hayne’s speech so that it leaves scarcely the wreck to be seen— There was also in the National Journal a third part of a speech of Barton, Senator from Missouri in the same debate; as severe upon Benton his Colleague as Webster’s upon Hayne— This debate is a symptom of the Times— Personalities, malignities and hatreds seem to take the place of all enlarged
discussions of public concerns.— I read also yesterday and this day the 11th book of the Epistles to Atticus— There are 25 of them, written partly while he was with Pompey in Greece, and partly at Brundisium where after the battle of Pharsalia he returned, and where he remained a whole year, not daring to return to Rome without the permission of Caesar. In his calamity his brother Quintus with his Son, not only deserted him, but endeavoured to make their own Peace with Caesar by accusing him— In the 6th. Letter of this book Cicero tells Atticus that in Pompey’s camp they talked of nothing but proscriptions in the Event of success; and that they had avowed projects for seizing the Estate of Atticus himself.
24. V:15. Ash Wednesday

Mrs Tudor called upon me to say that there was here an Italian Gentlemen, who had a Letter from General Washington written to his father, and who wished to pay me a visit. I received him, and his name is Dal Verme, brother to one of the same name who visited me three or four Summers since at Quincy. This person like his brother appears to be merely a visitor of curiosity. He has been three or four Months in this Country at Boston—New-York &c— He told me that before he came to this Country he had visited Russia and Persia; about the latter of which I asked him some questions— He told me that the Shah of Persia had about two hundred children— That eleven of them were Governors of Provinces; and that was the Reason why he had prevailed upon Russia to recognize Abbas Mirza, by Treaty as his Successor. Mr Westbrook and Mr Rapalje, are from Fish-kill Landing, and brought Letters of Introduction from my niece Mrs De Wint. The propose leaving the city to return home to-morrow Morning. I finished the Chapter upon Turkey in 1828 and commenced that upon the campaign of 1829. This last is the most arduous part of the work which now absorbs too exclusively my time— I am reading over the second Time an Article in the Quarterly Review of last November, upon European Turkey; an Article of 44 pages, reviewing four books upon Turkey and the whole purport of which is to shew that the Ottoman Nation “is the bitterest enemy to the human race, and the severest scourge that was ever sent by Providence to chastise mankind” and yet manifesting the most extreme anxiety for the preservation of its power; and the most unappeasable jealousy of Russia— At this second reading I observe with concern how little remained upon my memory of the first— Nor is it by many degrees the only evidence I have of the decay of Memory— It is vain to weep or pray upon this subject, but if it may render me suitably distrustful of the other faculties of the mind which must also be upon the decline—if it may render me less dogmatical in my own opinions and more charitable to those of others—if it may prepare me for resignation to the will ofHeaven under all the privations which must henceforth accumulate upon me, and if it may set me upon seeking with sincerity the means of protracting the possession of what remains; and of supplying it with aids and resources, the calamity may yet be mitigated, and old Age may be not without either its usefulness or its pleasures. I received this morning a Letter from Joseph Blunt, which I answered and sent him my fifth parcel of four sheets.
25. IV:30. Thursday.

I had a sprinkling of rain in my walk this morning. No visitor the whole day long except Mr T. B. Johnson— Working upon the campaign of 1829. with no other guide than the French Journal of St. Petersburg, and a very imperfect file of that— The bulletin’s and Reports from the commanding Generals are so copious that they would, make of themselves a large volume, but the task is to abridge, and to read at the same time with a Spirit of criticism, and it is military criticism— To select from a despatch of four or six folio pages, the incidents which constitute the import part of the transaction to reduce them within a narrow compass, and to connect them together in a regular chain of narrative is a task worthy of a thinking mind, and to compress the whole so as to make it interesting to the general reader is still more difficult— It severely tries my industry and intellect; and now absorbs at least six hours every day of my time. In the campaign of 1829. two Russian Armies, were in great and constant activity at the same time—one in Asia, the Army of the Caucasus— The other the Army upon and beyond the Danube, which finally crossed the Balkans and dictated Peace at Adrianople— The cotemporaneous movements of these army must be so managed in the narrative that they may not interfere with each other— This is new work to me, and presses anxiously upon me— John and Mary dined at Mr Frye’s. This evening I received a Letter from Mr George Washington Park Custis, of Arlington House— The other day, on the anniversary of Washington’s birthday, Mr Mitchell of Maryland moved for a Committee, to consider of a monument for Washington at the Capitol— A Committee of one member from each State was appointed— Mr Custis thinks that his Grandmother Mrs Washington consented to the transportation of her husbands remains to the Capitol, upon condition that she herself should be transported with him, and that some promise to that effect was made to her by my father. Mr Custis’s Letter was to enquire if there was any evidence of this in my father’s papers, and if there was, to request that I would communicate it to the Committee I examined the Papers and Letter Books that I have here; but found nothing.
26. VI:15— Friday.

Broad day-light again when I rose; and consequent procrastination of all my daily business— I answered however Mr Custis’s Letter— Dr Huntt called on me, and among other conversation told me that General Harrison had been yesterday to visit the President who received him very graciously, and assured him that his recall from the Republic of Colombia, was not caused by any hostility to him, but because the Instructions to the Panama Ministers contained some things offensive to Bolivar. Huntt said he had told Harrison that
in his place he would not have gone near a man, who had dismissed not only him but his Son from Office— But Harrison is of a forgiving disposition; and will very probably obtain another Office, under the present Administration— Mr Vance introduced Mr Neale, from the State of Ohio. Ames and Carew are two young men from Springfield, Massachusetts who came merely for curiosity’s sake; and introduced themselves— I asked Mr Brent to lend me from the Department of State Mills’s History of British India, which he promised— I have read the 12th. Book of the Epistles to Atticus— There are 53 of them, all short. Written after he had been relieved from the apprehension of being proscribed by Caesar; after the death of his daughter Tullia. Many of them relate to his project of building a Fane; as a permanent sepulchral Monument— He justifies himself for his extreme affliction at the loss of his daughter, and repeatedly declares that his only consolation is in writing for publication— There is more obscurity in these Letters than in those of the preceding Books— Many of them are intentionally obscure—broken hints— Allusions to things which had passed between them, and which would not have been understood even by his cotemporaries— The perpetual interlarding of Greek returns— In the time of his great distresses he had dropped his Greek— In the 49th. Letter there is a broad hint that he wishes Caesar may be assassinated— Eum συνναον Quirino malo quam Saluti— I had rather he should share a Temple with Quirinus than with Safety. If this Letter had been intercepted by Caesar he would have understood it in an instant. The Letters have much about purchasing Gardens; and much about his philosophical treatises which he was then composing: He mentions frequently his wife Terentia, but always so as not to disclose his meaning.
27. IV. Saturday. Sun rose 6:26.

I rose at four and walk round the Capitol Square, returning before Sun-rise: but from the eastern window he is intercepted. I had no visitors, but was closely engaged all day in the Russian and Turkish War pushing on with the Campaign of Count Paskevitch of Erivan in 1829— This is mere drudgery, to pick out a connected narrative from a succession of Reports and Bulletins— There is also the inconvenience that all these materials are of one side—the Turks having neither bulletins nor printing presses. It is probable that if the other side should also tell their story, the Russian victories would not be quite so splendid, and would appear to have been rather more dearly purchased. There is some difficulty in abridging narratives of sieges and battles; and for a person not practically familiar with them some hazard of committing ridiculous blunders— But I drive through my work, hoping that it will take me not more than another fortnight— I read twenty Letters of the 13th. Book of the Epistles to Atticus— They appear to have been written principally at Asturae— They relate among other things to his composition of the Books de Oratore de Finibus the Academic Questions, and de Officiis— He was long determining whether to address one of the Books to Varro or not— Also of the persons whom he shall introduce as Interlocutors. He speaks with high self-approbation upon the books de Oratore— The Letters are again filled with Greek; and his language is very difficult to understand, having been purposefully written
as he says in one place αφεϛερος, and in another διa σεμειων. What he apprehended his correspondent himself would not understand cannot be very easy to a reader of this age, and the Graeco Latin Glossary in the Clavis does not always explain the Greek words so as to make them intelligible— I have also read in the English Quarterly Review an Article upon the Life and writings of Dr Samuel Parr, which has led me to some reflections— Parr was a whig, and the greatest Classical Scholar in England. The reviewer is a Tory, and while acknowledging the Genius and Learning, and amiable character of Parr, constantly labours to make him ridiculous; and to disparage the application of his Talents— There needs another side of the subject to be seen: for the Reviewer makes out his case, by shewing the grossest inconsistencies of opinion, in Parr’s correspondence, and although there are eight Volumes of the Works there is no one great work to go down to Posterity— The criticisms upon the Sermons, upon the Epitaphs, upon the Style of Parr, are written in a Spirit of unkindness; but are yet plausible— Living it is good to receive instruction from an enemy Dead, it is glorious to receive extorted commendation from a foe— We saw this day the death of Mrs P. C. Brooks, announced in the New-York American— She died last Sunday A heavy loss to her husband and family—
28. V:30. Sunday.

Morning fair. Day Spring like— Evening clouding up. Mrs. Adams and John went with me and heard Mr Campbell from Matthew 6.19. [“]Lay not up for yourselves treasures upon earth, where moth and rust doth corrupt, and where thieves break through and steal 20, but lay up for yourselves treasures in heaven, where neither moth nor rust doth corrupt, and where thieves do not break through nor steal: 21 For where your treasure is, there will your heart be also.” After this morning’s service, I had visits from Mr Barrell, who introduced Mr Bruin a stranger from New-York, and from Coll. Dwight. I asked him to enquire of Mr Webster, if he had within the last fortnight sent me a note which had received no answer; and told him that yesterday for the first time, I had heard there was such a note, which had been delivered to a servant at the door, but which I had never received— He promised to make the enquiry, and to let me know. Mr White of Florida called upon me this afternoon, and brought me Mrs White’s Album, in which she requested that I would write some lines. White says that the Judiciary committee of the Senate have unanimously reported against the confirmation, of two nominations to office in Florida, against which he protested; and he had no doubt they would be rejected. He told me of a conversation he had lately entertained with Calhoun the Vice-President, in which White suggested to him the injudiciousness of the violent attacks of his partizans against New-England— That Van-Buren was taking advantage of it, and might have the whole Eastern influence thrown into his scale by it which otherwise Calhoun might expect for himself— He said Calhoun appeared to be exceedingly at a loss what to do. Said that he had been obliged by his position to take the lead in the opposition to Mrs Eaton— That he did not know what things were coming to—
That the payment of a National debt was in any Country a Revolution— That he had no feeling of unfriendliness to me, and would now have visited me, but for fears of its being misrepresented— That if I would have consulted him four years ago, and not have appointed Mr Clay Secretary of State, I should now have been President of the United States &c— White had this conversation with Calhoun, at the suggestion of Mr Webster—who told him that he should hold his course Independent of all parties; and should play second fiddle to no man— But wondered that Mr Calhoun did not see his own interest to avoid indisposing all New-England against him— White said Calhoun professed to have no apprehension that Clay would ever again be a formidable candidate for the Presidency— He also told me that Troup had resigned his Seat as a Senator from Georgia, and that W. H. Crawford would be appointed in his place— Mrs Adams and Mrs Smith spent the Evening at T. B. Johnson’s. I heard Mr Campbell again in the Evening from 1. Corinthians 10.11. “Now all these things happened unto them for ensamples: and they are written for our Admonition, upon whom the ends of the world are come.” It was the closing Lecture of a Series of biographies from the Scriptures, both of the old and new Testament: and he gave notice that he should now commence another Series, upon the parables of our Saviour.

Day. Scarcely any variation from the last Month. I have this month written 50 pages of Russian and Turkish War, and have another Months labour, in prospect, before I can expect to finish— Where wilds immeasurably spread, seem lengthening as I go.
